text.value:
A set is a collection of objects, which we refer to as elements. In many cases, the elements are just numbers. The cardinality of a set is just it's size. For example, {1,2,3} is the set whose elements are numbers 1, 2 and 3. It's cardinality is 3, because it has three elements. On the other hand, the set {0, 1, 2, 3, 4} has five elements, the integers from 0 to 4, so it's cardinality is 5.

We write {1,2,3} ⊂ {0,1,2,3,4} to indicate that the first set is contained in the second, or to use alternative language, the first set a subset of the second.

For infinite sets, like the set of integers, we may use an ellipsis "..." to denote that the elements "go on forever."

{1,2,3,...} The set of positive integers or natural numbers
{0,±1,±2,±3,...} The set of all integers

We also use special characters to represent some of these sets: you should be familiar with the symbols used to represent the set of integers, the set of natural numbers, the set of rational numbers and the set of real numbers.

Drag and drop the following sets into the spaces below to show the order of containment.
N is the set of natural numbers; Z is the set of integer; Q is the set of rational numbers and R is the set of real numbers.
